content:
Scotland’s former first minister faces 14 charges, including attempted rape

ONE OF THE more extraordinary things about the Scottish National Party (SNP) is how popular it remains, even as it enters its 12th year in government in Edinburgh. Despite the trials of office and the efforts of opposition parties to sink the nationalist project, the SNP has sailed serenely on. Polls put its support around the 40% mark, while the Conservatives and Labour scrap it out for second spot in the 20s. At around the same point in its life-cycle the New Labour government, that other recent election-winning behemoth, was occasionally slipping into third behind the Liberal Democrats.

But the SNP’s smooth progress has hit an iceberg. On January 24th Alex Salmond, the party’s 64-year-old former leader, who from 2007 to 2014 was Scotland’s first minister, was charged with nine sexual assaults, two attempted rapes, two indecent assaults and one breach of the peace. He denies them all.

Mr Salmond is the most important figure in the SNP’s history. He took the party into government and led it to an unexpectedly close 55%-45% vote against independence in the referendum of 2014. His successor as leader and first minister, Nicola Sturgeon, has long described him as her mentor and friend. Their close relationship has been crucial to the party’s gravity-defying success.

That relationship now looks wrecked. When allegations against Mr Salmond were made by two female civil servants last year, the Scottish government began an investigation, after which the police were called in. Mr Salmond is said to feel betrayed by his protégée, while Ms Sturgeon’s aides accuse his team of trying to smear her. The row has opened up wounds that will not heal.

The wider consequences of the Salmond case could be significant. Ms Sturgeon insists that her timetable for calling another independence referendum remains unchanged, and that she will set out her plans before Britain’s departure from the European Union, which is due on March 29th. In reality it is hard to see how the SNP could mount an independence campaign with the charges against Mr Salmond hanging in the air. Much will depend on the outcome of the case against him.

Further, Ms Sturgeon is herself in hot water. It has emerged that she had five private conversations with Mr Salmond during her government’s investigation into the complaints, including two meetings at her home. It took her two months to report the conversations to her civil servants. An inquiry is under way into whether she breached the ministerial code. More may follow. The first minister is also struggling to hold on to her permanent secretary, Leslie Evans, who oversaw the initial investigation into Mr Salmond. The former leader challenged the fairness of the process in court and won, after it emerged that the civil servant who led the probe had links to the complainants. Ms Evans’ days could be numbered.

The next election to the Holyrood parliament in Edinburgh is due in May 2021. Few have been predicting a change at the top. The SNP has followed a straightforward recipe for success, choosing leftish policies where it can and blaming Westminster-imposed austerity where it can’t. It has avoided the ideological extremes that have come to define the two big British parties, and kept its dignity amid the Brexit-related chaos that reigns elsewhere. Compared with what else is on offer, the SNP has to many Scots seemed competent, united and humane.

Those qualities now look less certain. The party’s reputation for competence has taken a blow over its handling of the accusations. Its claim to an uncommon level of internal unity has been blown apart. Its progressive credentials—Ms Sturgeon has been at pains to promote women, and women-friendly policies such as expanded childcare—are under a shadow. Whatever the result of the Salmond case, some voters may reach a new verdict on the SNP.

Title: Alex Salmond’s sex charges rock the SNP
